Haibo Zhao is a professor in the School of Energy and Power Engineering at Huazhong University of Science and Technology. Prof. Haibo Zhao is also a Fellow of the Combustion Institute. His research interests include the low-carbon combustion and high-value utilization of fossil fuels, as well as the flame synthesis of functional nanoparticles. He has been supported by the National Science Fund for Distinguished Young Scholars of China, Alexander von Humboldt Foundation, etc. His research work won the Distinguished Paper Award in the 38th International Symposium on Combustion, and the Best Paper Award in the 3rd International Conference on Chemical Looping, etc. He served as an editorial board member or associate editor of Energy & Fuels, Engineering, and Energy Environmental Focus. This work was supported by the National Key Research and Development Program of China ( 2022YFA1504801 ), the National Natural Science Foundation of China ( 22138009 ), and the Fundamental Research CO2 methanation has a potential in the large-scale utilization of carbon dioxide. It has also been considered to be useful for the renewable energy storage. The commercial pipeline for natural gas transportation can be directly applied for the methane product of CO2 methanation. The supported ruthenium (Ru) catalyst has been confirmed to be active and stable for CO2 methanation with its high ability in the dissociation of hydrogen and the strong binding of carbon monoxide. CO2 methanation over the supported Ru catalyst is structure sensitive. The size of the Ru catalyst and the support have significant effects on the activity and the mechanism. A significant challenge remained is the structural controllable preparation of the supported Ru catalyst toward a sufficiently high low-temperature activity. In this review, the recent progresses in the investigations of the supported Ru catalysts for CO2 methanation are summarized. The challenges and the future developments are also discussed. Graphical Abstract This paper reviews the recent progresses in the investigations of the supported ruthenium catalysts for CO2 methanation, with a focus on the controllable preparation and the structural effects. The challenges and prospects are also discussed. Keywords Ruthenium Carbon dioxide Methanation Hydrogenation Catalyst and metal-support interaction 1 Introduction With the increasing concerns on global warming and the rapid development in the renewable energy technologies, significant efforts are being made towards the capture and utilization of carbon dioxide [1–7], the largest man-made greenhouse gas. Among various options for the utilization of carbon dioxide, CO2 hydrogenation to methane, or CO2 methanation, attracts significantly increasing attentions because it has great potential for a large-scale utilization of carbon dioxide [8–17]. The reaction is also well known as Sabatier reaction. The product, methane, has been extensively applied as a clean fuel and feedstock for synthesis of various chemicals. The reaction has been also considered as a potential way for energy storage. The commercial pipeline for transportation of natural gas is ready for the methane product from the potential CO2 methanation at the remote site. CO2 methanation is thermodynamically favorable (CO2 + 4H2 ⇋ CH4 + 2H2O (g), ΔG°298 K = –114 kJ/mol). It is an exothermal reaction (∆H°298 K = –165.0 kJ/mol) [11–14,18–22]. There exists a competitive side reaction to carbon monoxide (CO2 + H2 ⇋ CO + H2O (g), ∆H°298 K = 41.2 kJ/mol), called as the reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction [11–14,18–22]. The RWGS reaction is an endothermic one. The higher reaction temperature favors this side RWGS reaction with the formation of CO. Theoretically, the low temperature operation is favored for CO2 methanation. However, there exists kinetic limitation in the methanation of CO2. Higher reaction temperature helps to overcome the kinetic limitation. A good catalyst is thus required to get a sufficiently high reaction rate at low reaction temperatures for CO2 methanation [18,19]. A significant challenge remains for the development of catalysts with high activity at temperatures at and below 200 °C. In some cases, a catalyst with high activity at elevated temperature for selective hydrogenation of CO2 to methane is also needed [20–22]. Noble metal and non-noble metal catalysts, normally supported by the oxides (like Al2O3, SiO2, ZrO2, TiO2, CeO2 and others), have been investigated for CO2 methanation [23–31]. The supported nickel catalysts are the most investigated ones, while the supported Rh, Pd and Ru are also exploited. Normally these kinds of noble metal catalysts exhibit high activity with high methane selectivity, typically at elevated temperatures [32,33]. Especially, increasing publications on the supported Ru catalysts for CO2 methanation can be found in the literature. The Ru catalyst is relatively cheap, compared to other noble metal catalysts. It shows high methane selectivity and high stability for CO2 methanation with its high ability in the dissociation of hydrogen and CO binding [34,35]. The supported Ru catalysts are structure sensitive for CO2 methanation. The catalyst size, the support and the strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) have remarkable effect on the activity, selectivity and stability for CO2 methanation. In this review, we attempt to summarize the recent progresses in the studies of the supported Ru catalysts for CO2 methanation. The challenges in the understanding of the structural effects and also in the structural controllable preparation are addressed. The future developments are finally presented. 2 The reaction mechanism Compared to the studies of the supported nickel catalysts for CO2 methanation, fewer published works can be found in the literature for the supported Ru catalysts. As above mentioned, the competitive RWGS reaction exists during CO2 methanation over the Ru catalyst. The product selectivity can be theoretically tailored by the active center of the catalyst [36]. It was reported that the bulk Ru has two crystalline structures, including facet-centered cubic (fcc) and hollow close-packed (hcp) [37]. The later one is more stable in terms of formation energy. Among various reported surface orientations ((0001) [33,38,39], (101–1) [40] and (112–1) [41]) for hcp ruthenium, the (0001) surface is most widely investigated. Compared to the ideal smooth one, it is easier for the reaction to take place on surfaces with unique sites (steps, corners, islands) or defects (vacancies, holes) due to the stronger electron transfer with reactants [42]. Similarly, the concavo-convex B5-site of Ru has been confirmed to be active in several reactions including CO2 methanation [33,43,44]. In particular, the formation of methane on the bridged-sites is more favored from mono-HCOO* instead of trans-COOH* [45]. However, on the stepped sites with large surface for the adsorption of H adatoms, the formation of CO* species can be further hydrogenated to HCO* and then to CH4 [38]. Notably, the exposed sites of ruthenium are strongly linked to the size and structure of the Ru catalyst, the basicity of the support, the reducibility of the support, the Ru/support interface and the strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) effect, including the conventional SMSI and the electronic metal-support interaction (EMSI), thus causing profound influences on the reaction mechanism. The mechanism is thus not a simple issue. There are multi-influencing factors that play important roles in the formation of final products or in the determination of the product selectivity and the reaction mechanism as well. The activation and subsequent conversion of carbon dioxide can be fulfilled on the multifunctional catalytic sites available at the metal/oxide interface in virtue of the synergy between the metal nanoparticles and the oxide support [10]. The surface hydroxyl species on the support can also involve in the reaction through the addition of H atoms of hydroxyl groups into CO2 to form HCOO* as the intermediate [4]. Yan et al. [16] employed a structural model of hydroxylated c-Al2O3 (100) supported Ru9 monolayer (Ru9/OH-Al2O3) to investigate the effect of surface hydroxyl groups in CO2 hydrogenation. Both the reaction energy and the energy barrier become much lower than those observed on the hydroxyl-free Ru9/Al2O3 model. This suggests the acceleration effect of the adjacent hydroxyl groups on the processes of CO2 activation and CO formation. Chen and his co-workers [10] proposed a general reaction network for CO2 methanation. Based on this reaction network, a modified reaction network is presented here for the supported Ru catalyst, as shown in Fig. 1 . This modified reaction network was made with the references of reaction mechanism studies on the un-supported [46] and supported [3,4,13,47–49] Ru catalysts for CO2 methanation. From Fig. 1, a complicated reaction network can be found. As shown in Fig. 1, there are three general pathways for CO2 methanation over the Ru catalyst. One is the formate pathway (CO2* + H* → HCOO*; blue path) and two other CO related pathways. The CO related pathways are based on the way for CO2 dissociation. One is the direct CO2 dissociation via the redox mechanism (CO2* → CO* + O*; yellow path). The other is the hydrogen assisted CO2 dissociation via carboxylate intermediates (CO2* + H* → COOH*; red path). H* is from dissociation of hydrogen (H2 → H* + H*). According to literature [50], the CO* related pathway is more favorable at low temperatures than the HCOO* pathway. However, the design and preparation of a catalyst that allows the reaction to proceed along a specific reaction pathway remains a significant challenge [24,50]. Each pathway includes several sub-branches for the conversion. The same chemical intermediate may lead to methane or carbon monoxide with different sub-branches. Especially, methanol has been expected to be a selective product by Chen et al. [10], as shown in Fig. 1. For the supported Ru catalyst, this has not been experimentally confirmed until the In2O3 [48,51,52] and In2O3-ZrO2 [49] supports were applied. From Fig. 1, multi-products can be formed from CO2 hydrogenation. To achieve a highly selective hydrogenation of carbon dioxide, a good catalyst is mandatory. With its superior ability in CO binding and the dissociation of hydrogen, the supported Ru nanoparticle catalyst shows high methane selectivity and high stability for CO2 methanation. 3 Thermodynamic analyses With the consideration of the reactions for CO2 methanation, the competitive RWGS reaction and carbon formation reaction from CO2 and H2 (CO2 + 2H2 → C (s) + 2H2O (g), ∆H°298 K = −90.147 kJ/mol) should not be ignored. According to our analyses of thermodynamic equilibrium (Fig. 2(a) ), when the reaction temperature is higher than 600 °C, CO derived from the RWGS reaction dominates the product in CO2 hydrogenation, while methane formation is un-favored. This result is consistent with the studies by Jia et al. [53] and Su et al. [14]. Meanwhile, the formation of carbon deposits can be normally prohibited to a great extent when the temperature is below 600 °C [14]. As shown in Figs. 2(b) and 2(c), high pressure is more beneficial to the CO2 methanation process. Moreover, the increasing H2/CO2 feed ratio has a positive effect on CO2 conversion and the selectivity of methane (Figs. 2(d) and 2(e)). In general, to achieve a selective methane formation from CO2 hydrogenation, the side RWGS reaction has to be inhibited. The reaction has to be thus carried out at reasonably low temperatures, as far away from the optimal range of the RWGS reaction for CO formation. For example, with the CO2 hydrogenation reaction at a fitted CO2/H2 ratio of 1/4, which corresponds to a desired stoichiometry ratio for CO2 methanation reaction, the optimized operation temperature should not be higher than 400 °C. In the case of reaction condition with the CO2/H2 ratio of 1/3, the optimized operation temperature should not be higher than 350 °C. As such, it is very important to get a good catalyst that can efficiently accelerate the reaction rate of CO2 methanation at such low reaction temperatures and prohibit the competitive side RWGS reaction at elevated reaction temperatures. 4 The effect of catalyst size As is known the size of the nickel catalyst has a significant influence on CO2 methanation [11]. Similar to the supported Ni catalyst, CO2 methanation over the supported Ru catalyst is also strong size-dependent [8,46,47,54,55]. Guo et al. [54] modulated the size of the Ru catalysts on ceria nanowire and thus disclosed the competitive relationship between the SMSI effect and the H-spillover in determining the methanation activities. Ceria supported single Ru atoms (Ru(SA)/CeO2), Ru clusters (Ru(NC)/CeO2, ca. 1.2 nm), and large Ru nanoparticles (Ru(NP)/CeO2, ca. 4.0 nm), as shown in Figs. 3(a)–(f) , were investigated. Among them, Ru(NC)/CeO2 shows the highest activity for low-temperature CO2 methanation (190 °C) with the methane selectivity close to 100% and the TOF of 7.41 × 10–3 s–1. The negative CO2 reaction order decreases their absolute values from single atoms to clusters, which turns positive in nanoparticles. However, it shows the opposite tendency for the positive H2 reaction order. The CO route was identified to dominate the whole reaction process, in which metal carbonyls are the critical intermediates and the active centers are those Ce3+-OH sites. The Ru sites neighboring the metal-support interfaces are responsible for CO2 dissociation and carbonyl hydrogenation, respectively. The strongest SMSI effect was found in the supported single Ru atoms, whereas the strongest H-spillover effect exists in the supported Ru nanoparticles. The corresponding activation of metal carbonyls and the dehydration of the support surfaces are greatly suppressed. It is notable that these two factors can reach a balance in the CeO2-supported Ru clusters and the methanation reactivity is thus maximized. Liang et al. [12] found that hydroxyl groups have a positive effect on the Ru dispersion. They mixed rutile TiO2 and palygorskite via a strong electrostatic absorption method. The abundant hydroxyl groups of palygorskite significantly improve the Ru dispersion and yield very fine nanoparticles. The obtained Ru-TiO2/palygorskite catalyst shows an excellent CO2 methanation performance with 100% selectivity of methane and high stability during a 60-h catalytic test at 450 °C. Navarro-Jaén et al. [56] reported the size effect of larger ruthenium nanoparticles. By means of the polyol method, ruthenium nanoparticles supported on γ-Al2O3 are proved to be size-tailored (15–30 nm). They found an increased population of sites for the H2 adsorption over the large ruthenium nanoparticles. The CO2 conversion as well as CH4 yield are thus increased, which can be explained by the variation of apparent activation energies (Fig. 3(g)). Abe et al. [57] applied a barrel-sputtering to prepare highly dispersed Ru nanoparticles on anatase TiO2 with a narrow particle-size distribution and a mean diameter of ca. 2.5 nm. A 100% yield of methane was achieved for CO2 methanation at ca. 160 °C, which is more than 200 °C below that required for Ru/TiO2 prepared by the conventional wet impregnation method with large particle size. Apart from the experimental studies, the theoretical insights into the size effect are also important. For instance, Ma et al. [46] found that the coordination number (CN) of Ru-Ru has a significant effect on the CO2 methanation by DFT calculation and the micro-kinetic simulation with Ru n /Ru(0001) (n = 1, 2, 3, 4) model catalysts. For the low Ru-Ru coordination numbers (CN = 3, 4, 5, and 5.5), the dominant pathway for CO2 methanation is CO2* → CO* → COH* → C* → CH* → CH2* → CH3* → CH4*. The methane selectivity increases with the increasing Ru-Ru CNs. On Ru1/Ru(0001), carbon monoxide is the dominant product, while methane is the main product on Ru4/Ru(0001). However, Ru3/Ru(0001) shows the highest TOF for RWGS and methanation. Their study suggests that the single atom Ru catalyst is more favored for RWGS reaction to generate CO, while the high methanation activity needs the Ru nanoparticle. Table 1 presents the adsorption energies of some important intermediates with configurations of CO2* and CO*+O* on Run/Ru(0001) [46]. From Table 1, the size dependent performances of the Ru catalysts are clearly demonstrated. Ma et al. [55] further investigated the CeO2 supported Ru catalyst. They found that the oxygen vacancy (Ov) of CeO2 affects the interaction between the Ru n cluster and the support by changing the Ru–O bond number. For the smaller Ru n cluster, especially, the single atom (Ru1), more Ru–O bonds formed lead to more stable Ru n clusters. With larger Ru n cluster, Ov has less impact on the binding energy of Ru n and CeO2. This causes significant changes in the catalyst structure, leading to further changes in the adsorption and conversion, as illustrated in Fig. 3(h). For Ru1/CeO2, the active site is the Ru atom with the nearby lattice O atoms. CO2 methanation undergoes a carboxylate intermediate (COOH*) route with higher barriers for the elementary steps (H2(g) → 2H* and CO* + H* → HCO*). For the Ru4/CeO2 catalyst, CO2 dissociation becomes the dominant pathway with the highest turnover frequency and the lowest apparent activation energy, among the CeO2 supported Ru1, Ru4 and Ru8 catalysts investigated. The moderate adsorption strength and the lower apparent activation energy explain why Ru4 has high reactivity for CO2 methanation [55]. Similarly, Hensen and his co-workers [47] also carried out a comparative theoretical study of a single Ru atom on CeO2 (Ru1/CeO2), a Ru6/CeO2 and a Ru doped CeO2 catalyst (Ru6/RuCe x–1O2x–1) for CO2 methanation. They found that Ru1/CeO2 can only break one of the C–O bonds in adsorbed CO2. It is only active for RWGS reaction. In contrast, Ru6/CeO2 and Ru6/RuCe x–1O2x–1 are active for CO2 methanation via hydrogen assisted pathway. A higher CO2 methanation rate is predicted for Ru6/RuCe x–1O2x–1 since it has a lower activation energy for HCO dissociation, caused by stronger electron-electron repulsion due to its closer proximity to Ru. Strong H2 adsorption on small Ru clusters explains the higher CO2 methanation activity of Ru clusters on CeO2. To sum up, from the reported works, the size of the ruthenium catalyst has significant influence on the activity and selectivity of the supported Ru catalyst for CO2 methanation. Based on the discussions in the literature [46,47,54–57], the size effect of the supported ruthenium catalysts is schematically illustrated in Fig. 4 . To achieve a highly selective CO2 methanation, Ru clusters or nanoparticles are normally required, as addressed above and below. An exception is the supported Ru catalysts with classic SMSI effect, which will be also discussed below. 5 The effect of the support The support plays important role in the Ru catalyst for CO2 methanation. A suitable support is mandatory for an active catalyst. Otherwise, the catalytic activity cannot be guaranteed [28]. The support controls the distribution of the catalyst, stabilizes the dispersed Ru species and provides the sites for CO2 adsorption and reactions. The metal (Ru)-support interaction has special influences on the activity, selectivity and stability. The Ru-support interaction induces charge transfer, the formation of Ru/support interfacial active sites, changes in the morphology and chemical composition of the catalyst, as discussed by Prof. de Jong and his co-workers [58]. The SMSI effect in the supported Ru catalyst can even cause a total change in the selectivity for CO2 hydrogenation, as discussed below. 5.1 Reducible oxides The reducible oxides like CeO2, ZrO2, TiO2, In2O3 and others have been used as the support of various Ru catalysts for CO2 methanation. A unique characteristic of the reducible oxide is the oxygen vacancy, which has shown significant effect on the catalytic properties for CO2 methanation. The basicity of CeO2 and ZrO2 is also helpful for the adsorption of carbon dioxide. Duan and his co-workers [59] found that the oxygen vacancy of CeO2 plays an important role in the enhanced low temperature activity of Ru/CeO2 catalyst for CO2 methanation. They confirmed that oxygen vacancy, Ce3+, and surface hydroxyl in Ru/CeO2 catalyst participate in the catalytic process via the formate pathway, while the oxygen vacancy catalyzes the formate dissociation to methanol, which is the rate-determining step. The further hydrogenation of methanol causes the formation of methane. Based on the operando characterization, they confirmed that, in the reduction process, oxygen vacancy, Ce3+ and surface hydroxyl in Ru/CeO2 catalyst are gradually generated with the reduction of Ru species during the elevation of temperature, starting at ~100 °C. The structural evolvement mechanism is illustrated in Fig. 5 [59]. At first, the Ru ion is reduced to metallic Ru, which dissociates hydrogen. The dissociated hydrogen atom then attacks Ce–O bond on CeO2 surface, which generates the surface hydroxyl, Ce3+, and oxygen vacancy. The hydrogen-spillover effect of metallic Ru would facilitate the attacking of hydrogen atom toward Ce–O bond on the substrate surface. To further confirm the role of oxygen vacancy, Ru/α-Al2O3 (without oxygen vacancy) was also prepared [59]. The oxygen vacancy of Ru/CeO2 catalyzes the rate-determining step with a much lower activation temperature, compared with the Ru surface in Ru/α-Al2O3 (125 vs. 250 °C). A significantly higher activity is achieved over Ru/CeO2 [59,60]. Different from Ru/CeO2, Ru/α-Al2O3 takes carboxylic route for CO2 methanation with the absence of oxygen vacancy. This demonstrates an active site dependent catalytic mechanism toward CO2 methanation. Sharma et al. [61] applied a combustion method to prepare Ce0.96Ru0.04O2 and Ce0.95Ru0.05O2 catalyst. These catalysts show a 55% CO2 conversion with a 99% methane selectivity at a temperature of 450 °C. They believed that the activity was comparable to the best catalysts reported previously for CO2 methanation. The characterization shows that the methanation reaction occurs on the reduced Ce0.95Ru0.05O2 catalyst, while the role of the dopant is to make the reduction possible at a lower temperature than on pure ceria. This mechanism is different from other CeO2 based catalysts but still unclear. Further investigation is needed. The studies above mentioned strongly suggested that CeO2 can directly involve in the reactions for CO2 methanation. López-Rodríguez et al. [62] investigated the roles of Ru and CeO2 for CO2 methanation. Exposure of the CO2 + H2 methanation mixture on the Ru metal and CeO2 results in the partial reoxidation of these surfaces via CO2 dissociative chemisorption at room temperature, as confirmed by the near ambient pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (NAP-XPS). CO2 chemisorption on both Ru and CeO2, simulated by DFT studies, well supports the oxidative nature of the process. H2 activation and dissociation under CO2 methanation conditions can take place on both the Ru phase, which is an almost barrierless process, as well as on the CeO2–x (111) surface with a low activation barrier, leading to high H and OH coverages, respectively [62]. As for ceria, surface hydroxylation is conducive to the retention of CO2, while the opposite is predicted for Ru. Such complementarity is reckoned to cause a positive impact on the overall reactivity, allowing additional sites for CO2 adsorption that are predicted to be accessible to Ru at the Ru/CeO2 interface. The overall rate-determining step in the CO2 methanation on the Ru/CeO2 catalyst is the hydrogenation of Ru-carbonyls, of which the energy barrier is 2.16 eV. On ceria, CO2 prefers to accumulate on the surface in the form of strongly bound carbonates, while carboxylates located over oxygen vacancies are thermodynamically-driven to the generation of formate species [62]. It takes a considerable activation energy for the evolution of the latter stable species. In this way, they remain adsorbed on the ceria surface up to 200 °C. At higher temperatures, formates can decompose to CO and thus yield ruthenium carbonyls. On the other hand, at temperatures lower than 200 °C, carboxylates are very reactive, leading to CO and O*, regenerating the oxygen vacancy and causing the Ru-carbonyls observed at room temperature via a spillover mechanism. Unlike CeO2, despite that Ru shows a very weak CO2 binding, an incipient ruthenium reoxidation is also observed in CO2 methanation even at room temperature. Such Ru oxidation is bound to be related to the synergistic Ru-CeO2 interactions, either by oxygen spillover from ceria at the interfacial sites or by enabling highly active interfacial sites, which exhibit strong capability to split CO2 and to stabilize CO. Wang et al. [63] compared the activities of Ru/CeO2, Ru/SiO2, Ru/MgO and Ru/γ-Al2O3 for CO2 methanation. They found that Ru/CeO2 shows a much higher CO2 conversion (up to 86%) and CH4 selectivity (up to 100%), as well as excellent stability of 30 h due to the existence of abundant oxygen vacancies and weak basic sites. They concluded the synergistic effect between oxygen vacancies and basic sites plays an important role in the high activity of Ru/CeO2. Tada et al. [64] prepared Ru/m-ZrO2 catalyst using a selective deposition method. A CO2 conversion of 82% was achieved at 250 °C with a more than 99% selectivity of methane. The catalytic performance kept unchanged for 70 h. This exceptional low-temperature performance is attributed to the robust interaction between Ru and m-ZrO2, which enhances the activation of CO2. The amorphous ZrO2 (am-ZrO2) was also used as the support [65]. As Ru/m-ZrO2, Ru/am-ZrO2 shows a high methane selectivity (> 99%) for CO2 methanation. However, the CO2 conversion is lower (73%) over Ru/am-ZrO2 at 250 °C. The oxygen vacancies also play important roles in Ru/ZrO2 for CO2 methanation. Chen et al. [66] made a Ru/ZrO2 catalyst with pronounced electronic metal-support interaction between Ru and ZrO2, caused by O-vacancies formed at or very close to the metal-oxide interface. A charge transfer from the O-vacancy to the Ru atoms, mainly to the Ru atoms at the interface, close to the O-vacancy, is thus induced. This modification of the electronic state of the Ru interface perimeter atoms is considered to be the main reason for enhanced activity for CO2 methanation with 100% selectivity of methane. Cisneros et al. [67] applied a MgO incorporation in ZrO2 for the improvement in the activity of Ru/ZrO2. The rate of methane formation on Ru/ZrO2-MgO with higher Ru dispersion is almost three-fold higher than that on Ru/ZrO2. They found that the substitution of zirconium cations (+4) by magnesium cations (+2) in the ZrO2 lattice promotes the generation of O-vacancies, facilitating electron transfer from them to the interfacial Ru sites. This not only enhances H2 activation but also impairs the stability of adsorbed bidentate formate, which subsequently decomposes to COads and then hydrogenates to methane at the Ru-support perimeter. Recently, we reported that the CO adsorption has a significant effect on the metal promoted In2O3 catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation [68]. The CO adsorption also has an effect on the Ru/ZrO2 catalyst for CO2 methanation. Gao et al. [69] used alkali metals (Li, Na and K) as promoters to improve the activity of Ru/ZrO2 for CO2 methanation. They found that sodium is the best among the three metals. Under 1.0 MPa, H2/CO2 =3 and 200 °C, the CO2 conversion over Ru/Na-ZrO2 (20.9%) is more than an order of magnitude higher than Ru/ZrO2 (1.2%). The methane selectivity for the two catalysts is the same (close to 100%). The CO2 conversion over Ru/Na-ZrO2 is also higher than the Li or K promoted catalysts (10.7% and 14.8%). The Ru catalyst size is around 1.0 and 1.4 nm for Ru/ZrO2 and Ru/Na-ZrO2, respectively. The addition of Na favors the bridge absorbed CO near the interfacial Ru sites with much lower dissociation barriers, caused by the enhanced electron back-donation from interfacial Ru to CO*. The increased conversion is related to the reduced dissociation barriers of bridge CO at the interfacial Ru site rather than the enriched charge density of Ru. However, a Na doped Ru/ZrO2 catalyst was reported with different catalytic performance [70], with which the sodium doping leads to RWGS reaction and reduces the methane selectivity. The Ru-support interface has been found to have significant effect on the properties of CO2 methanation catalysts. Liao et al. [71] studied the effect of the Ru-ZnO interfacial structure using ZnO nanoplate (p-ZnO), ZnO nanorod (r-ZnO) and ZnO nanoparticle (c-ZnO) catalysts. They found that the catalytic activity follows the order: Ru/p-ZnO > Ru/r-ZnO > Ru/c-ZnO, while the product selectivity is positively related with the strength of Ru-(CO)x,ad species. The Ru/p-ZnO catalyst with more low-coordination Ru species exhibits the highest CH4 selectivity. The reaction mechanism has been proposed with COad species as a key intermediate. 5.2 Non-reducible oxides Al2O3 has been used as the support of the Ru catalyst for CO2 methanation. Especially, the Ru/Al2O3 catalyst has been frequently used for the comparative studies of other supported Ru catalysts [59]. Jabotra et al. [72] compared the activity of γ-Al2O3 supported Ru and Ni catalysts for CO2 methanation. They confirmed that Ru/γ-Al2O3 has higher activity. For Ru/γ-Al2O3, CO2 conversion starts at 100–200 °C and reaches the maximum of 100% at 325 °C. Subsequently, the conversion gradually decreases with the increasing temperature. The methane selectivity shows a similar temperature dependence. At 325 °C, the methane selectivity is 100%. Above 350 °C, RWGS starts with the CO formation. On the other hand, for Ni/γ-Al2O3, the CO2 conversion starts above 50 °C. The maximum CO2 conversion is 59% at 375 °C. Subsequently, the CO2 conversion reduces beyond 375 °C. The methane selectivity shows the similar temperature dependence and the selectivity of CO is minimal at 375 °C. The Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst is most active at 375 °C with the highest conversion (59%) and maximum methane selectivity (52.5%). A catalyst size effect has been also observed with the Al2O3 supported Ru catalyst for CO2 methanation. Kwak et al. [73] found that, at low Ru loadings (≤ 0.5%), the active Ru phase is mostly atomically dispersed on the alumina support with CO as the domain product from the RWGS reaction. The atomically dispersed Ru catalyst is not stable during the reaction. Aggregated Ru clusters can be observed after the reaction. With increasing metal loading, the Ru metallic cluster is formed and the selectivity toward methane formation increases. The Ru cluster is favored for CO2 methanation reaction. Wang et al. [74] applied a boron-doped alumina to improve the stability of Ru catalyst on the support. The B-doped alumina support possesses coordinatively unsaturated penta-coordinated Al3+ (Alpenta 3+) sites. Ru atoms can be efficiently immobilized via the anchoring effect of the Alpenta 3+ site. The supported Ru catalyst is thus obtained for CO2 methanation. It shows a better catalytic performance in CO2 methanation along with a higher methane yield of 81.2% at 350 °C, 0.1 MPa, and 6000 mL gcat –1 h–1, compared to the Ru catalysts supported on commercial alumina and the defect-free alumina. Apart from Al2O3, SiO2 is another popular support for the catalyst investigations. Ni/SiO2 has been confirmed to be active for CO2 methanation [9]. However, the reported Ru/SiO2 catalysts were found to have low activity for CO2 methanation [65,75] with some exceptions [76]. For example, Nagase et al. [65] reported a Ru/SiO2 catalyst, with which the CO2 conversion is < 20% in the temperature range of 150–300 °C with a methane selectivity < 90%. However, the CO2 conversion of Ru/am-ZrO2 reaches 73% at 250 °C with ~100% of methane selectivity at the same reaction condition. 5.3 The effect of the surface hydroxyl species As above mentioned, the surface hydroxyl species on the support may have significant effect on the performance of the supported Ru catalyst for CO2 methanation. Xu et al. [77] employed a Cr3+-doping strategy to enhance the content of hydroxyl groups on the CeO2 surface. An improved low-temperature activity of Ru/CeO2 for CO2 methanation was achieved (Fig. 6(a) ). They found that CO2 tends to be adsorbed at OH* sites to produce HCO3* with a decreasing energy of 0.79 eV in the presence of surface OH*, as shown in Fig. 6(b). HCO3* is further hydrogenated to a-HCOO* by overcoming an activation energy of 0.93 eV. In the absence of surface OH*, CO2 prefers to be adsorbed at Ru sites to form b-CO2* with a decreasing energy of 0.71 eV. b-CO2* is then further hydrogenated to b-HCOO* by overcoming an activation energy of 1.15 eV. From their study [77], the generation of HCOO* from HCO3* is more kinetically favorable. The further hydrogenation of HCOO* leads to the formation of CH4*. Zhou et al. [78] prepared a TiO2 support with a large amount of hydroxyl by ion exchange between F– in TiOF2 and H– in NaBH4. The formation rate of methane on the obtained Ru/TiO2 catalyst exceeds that of Ru/Deggusa-P25 by 35% at 300 °C. The reduction process of the catalyst can also generate hydroxyl groups. Sharma et al. [79] reported that the substituted Ru has the ability to dissociate H2 and the dissociated hydrogen attacks the Ce–O bond on the CeO2 surface, which generates the surface hydroxyl, Ce3+, and oxygen vacancy, as shown in Fig. 6(c). They found that formate comes from the reaction of CO2 with surface hydroxyl on the CeO2 surface. Besides, Falbo et al. [80] also observed the symmetric and asymmetric –OCO– stretching vibrations of the adsorbed bicarbonate species, formed upon reaction between CO2 and the hydroxyl groups of the Al2O3 support, in the in-situ DRIFTS spectra of the Ru/Al2O3 catalyst. Similarly, the adsorption and activation of CO2 by hydroxyl groups also exist on the catalysts like Ru/Al2O3 [25,75,81–83], Ru/SiO2 [4], Ru-CeO2 [54,84], Ru/TiO2 [85] and Ru/MnO [86]. 5.4 The SMSI effect Bao and his co-workers [87] reported a Ru-MoO3 catalyst, prepared through a co-impregnation-calcination process with a Ru content of 1.9 wt%. A classic SMSI effect was observed with this Ru-MoO3 catalyst during the CO2 hydrogenation reaction above 250 °C. The defective MoO3–x overlayers from the MoO3 support can migrate onto the Ru nanoparticles during the reaction, which forms an encapsulation structure on the catalyst. The catalytic performance shifts from CO2 methanation over the exposed surface Ru sites to the RWGS catalyzed by oxygen vacancies in the MoO3–x layers via the quasi-MvK mechanism. The Ru-Mo-O x catalyst in the SMSI state shows 99.0% CO selectivity with high activity and high stability for RWGS reaction. This study suggests the oxide overlayer can be used to tune the selectivity of the Ru catalyst for CO2 methanation. Rui et al. [52] also reported a classic SMSI effect with the In2O3 supported Ru catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation. However, different from Ru-Mo-O x catalyst, the Ru/In2O3 catalyst leads to a highly selective methanol synthesis from CO2 hydrogenation [48,49,51,52]. This means In2O3 is a unique support. The EMSI between Ru and In2O3 causes a highly selective catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. The classic SMSI effect also presents in the Ru/TiO2 catalyst [76,88,89]. Zhang et al. [76] tuned the selectivity of CO2 hydrogenation at atmospheric pressure on a Ru/anatase-TiO2 catalyst via the SMSI effect. They found that, at temperatures < 210 °C, the CO2 conversion shows an increasing trend with temperature while keeping methane as the exclusive product via the methanation process. However, the product selectivity completely shifts from 100% CH4 to 100% CO at temperatures ≥ 210 °C, as shown in Fig. 7 . This suggests an unusual total shift from methanation reaction to RWGS reaction at such low reaction temperatures. The catalyst shows excellent catalytic stability for the methanation and RWGS reaction at 180 and 300 °C, respectively. Zhang et al. [76] compared the performance of pure a-TiO2, Ru/SiO2, Ru/CeO2, Ru/r-TiO2, and Ru/MoO3 under the identical reaction conditions. As shown in Fig. 7(b), a-TiO2 showed no activity at temperatures below 270 °C. A low CO2 conversion with single CO product was then observed at a higher reaction temperature (Fig. 7(b)). On Ru/SiO2, Ru/CeO2, and Ru/r-TiO2, 100% CH4 selectivity was observed for all the tested reaction temperatures (Figs. 7(c)–(e)). Ru/MoO3 shows a gradual evolution of CO in the product with increasing temperatures (Fig. 7(f)). It is the SMSI effect of Ru and anatase TiO2 that overturns the CO2 hydrogenation selectivity at low temperature. The catalyst characterization demonstrates that the exposed metallic Ru nanoparticles promote methane formation via formate intermediates at temperatures below 200 °C. The increasing temperature under H2-containing atmosphere causes a formation of active TiO x suboxide on the metal. The encapsulated structure changes the surface intermediate from formate to carboxy species during CO2 hydrogenation reaction. This leads to an exclusive CO formation with long-term catalytic stability. The treatment of the encapsulated structure with oxygen can make a cyclic switch of product selectivity between CO and methane. Exactly, the phase structure of titanium oxide has effect on the dispersion of Ru nanoparticles. Lin et al. [90] found that the rutile TiO2 is an ideal support to prohibit the aggregation of RuO2 after calcination. Compared with the Ru nanoparticles (4.0 ± 2.4 nm) supported on anatase TiO2, the rutile TiO2 supported ones exhibited a narrower particle size distribution (1.1 ± 0.2 nm). This unique property was attributed to the strong interaction between RuO2 and rutile TiO2 in terms of the formation of the Ru–O–Ti bond. Such strong interaction not only promotes the high dispersion of Ru nanoparticles to a great extent, but also prevents the undesired aggregation phenomenon. As a result, the Ru/rutile TiO2 catalyst exhibits much higher activity and thermal stability than the Ru/anatase TiO2 for CO2 methanation. Zhou et al. [91] observed a similar classic SMSI phenomenon over the Ru/anatase-TiO2 catalyst. They found that the metal-support interfacial compatibility can critically control MSI modes and catalytic performances in CO2 hydrogenation. Annealing Ru/rutile-TiO2 in air enhances CO2 conversion to methane, resulted from the enhanced interfacial coupling driven by matched lattices of RuO x with rutile-TiO2. The Ru NPs can strongly adhere to rutile-TiO2 and form flat particles with larger curvatures, in which interfacial RuO x species act as anchoring layers with rutile-TiO2. However, annealing Ru/anatase-TiO2 in air reduces CO2 conversion and shifts the product into CO owing to the SMSI effect, as indicated by Zhang et al [76]. The Si doping can effectively inhibit the classic SMSI effect of Ru/TiO2 catalyst with maintained high methane selectivity for CO2 hydrogenation, although the inhibition mechanism is not clear [92]. The Cr3+ cation doping can also improve the SMSI of Ru/rutile-TiO2 catalyst for enhanced CO2 methanation [93]. It was found that the Cr3+ doping in the lattice of r-TiO2 causes a formation of Cr doped TiO2 solid solution, A Ru/Ti0.95Cr0.05O2 catalyst with optimum doping content, higher dispersion of Ru and enhanced MSI than the Ru/r-TiO2 leads to linear-CO* intermediates, which are responsible for the much higher activity for CO2 methanation, compared to Ru/r-TiO2. In general, various oxide supported Ru catalysts have been investigated for CO2 methanation. When the reaction temperature is above 310 °C, the rare earth metal oxides (Gd2O3, Sm2O3 and Y2O3) supported Ru catalysts might show higher activity for CO2 methanation [75]. At the reaction temperature below 310 °C, however, TiO2 and, to a lesser extent, ZrO2 excel the other supports [75], while the Ru/CeO2 catalyst exhibits the highest activity, as shown in Table 2 [33,59–61,77, 88,89,94–98], with a comprehensive consideration of the conversions, selectivities and TOFs. Especially, CeO2 has a high ability in CO2 adsorption. This leads to a cyclic CO2 adsorption and methanation on the Ru/CeO2 catalyst, which is a simulation of a real use of the catalyst at 250 °C and atmospheric pressure [99]. As summarized by Ilsemann et al. [75], SiO2 has no support effect on the Ru catalyst for CO2 methanation. Al2O3 and MgO are involved in the reaction with their ability in CO2 adsorption. TiO2, ZrO2 and CeO2 provides unique sites for CO2 adsorption and affects the reactions via the EMSI effect [75]. The classic SMSI phenomena occurs for some TiO2 supported Ru catalysts, which shifts the selectivity from CO2 methanation to CO formation via RWGS. The SMSI effect above mentioned is schematically summarized in Fig. 8 . The oxide support can offer sites for CO2 adsorption, while Ru provides sites for H2 dissociation. The combination of the support and the Ru catalyst leads to the high CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity at low temperature. The Ru-CO2 coverage decreases with the support reducibility [95], while too much Ru-CO coverage reduces the number of H2 dissociation sites. It is important to control the reducibility of the oxide support to adjust the balance between CO coverage and H2 dissociation sites in order to ensure the optimal catalytic performance [95]. Because of the relatively fewer reported works on the supported Ru catalysts in the literature, it might be still too early to make a conclusion for the optimum support with the superior catalytic properties. 5.5 The non-oxide supports Increasing non-oxide supporting materials are being used for the preparation of the ruthenium catalysts. It extends the scope of the supporting materials for Ru catalysts. Some of these kinds of supports can form the structured Ru catalysts with unique catalytic performance for CO2 methanation. Tébar-Soler et al. [100] prepared a solid catalyst, RuO x C y @C, that contains Ru sites with low oxidation state by doping RuO2 with C atoms at interstitial positions of the crystal lattice using a mild hydrothermal synthesis strategy. The presence of carbon atoms in the ruthenium oxide crystal lattice contributes to a delay in the full reduction of Ru ion to the inactive Ru0 phase. The availability of Ru n+ sites introduces new Lewis active sites, which enable CO2 activation at temperatures as low as 50 °C. A 50% CO2 conversion was achieved at 180 °C, 20 bar and H2/CO2 molar ratio of 3, which corresponded to a space time yield (STY) of methane of 0.11 molCH4 h–1 g–1 (that is, 114.4 molCH4 L–1 h–1). Moreover, this RuO x C y @C catalyst was confirmed to be stable under intermittent power supply conditions [100]. This test is important for the future development, to meet the requirement of the electricity production systems based on renewable energies. Cored et al. [101] synthesized a core-shell catalyst, of which the core is metallic ruthenium and the shell is ruthenium carbide (RuC), by a mild hydrothermal treatment method. The surface RuC species were found to be active sites, which are capable of activating both CO2 and H2 with an extremely high activity for CO2 hydrogenation at low temperatures (160-200 °C) and 100% selectivity toward methane. A direct CO2 hydrogenation mechanism was proposed. Yang et al. [33] prepared Ru model nano-catalysts on the inert SiC support with the use of alumina, deposited by atomic layer deposition (ALD) to regulate the metal active sites for CO2 methanation. They found that the catalytic behaviors of Ru nano-catalysts are related to the exposed (0001) terrace sites of Ru nanoparticles through the HCOO* intermediate for further methanation. The porous hexagonal boron nitride (pBN) is an ideal catalyst support because of its high thermal stability and conductivity. Fan et al. [102] invented an atomic Ru catalyst immobilized on porous h-BN using vacuum filtration, with which the Ru precursor is quickly located at the defects of pBN. Through an annealing treatment, atomic Ru catalysts are restricted onto the defects via B, N coordinations, which reduce the valence state of atomic Ru. The as-prepared catalyst with low Ru loading (0.58 wt%) shows a CO2 conversion of 28.7% and a methane selectivity of 93.5% with a high reaction rate (1.86 mmolCO2 gcat –1 s–1) at 350 °C and 1.0 MPa. The catalyst keeps stable during a 110-h test. Both atomic-scale catalyst size and low valence state of Ru species supported on pBN are considered to be responsible for the improvement of methane production rate. 6 Conclusions and perspectives With the worldwide concerns on CO2 utilization, CO2 methanation over the supported Ru catalysts draws increasing attentions. The Ru catalyst is cheaper than other noble metal catalysts. It exhibits high methane selectivity and high stability with high activity for CO2 methanation thanks to its high ability in the dissociation of hydrogen and CO binding. From the investigations reported by far, the support has significant influences on the Ru catalysts. The support cannot only stabilize the highly dispersed Ru catalyst but also involve directly in the CO2 adsorption and surface reaction via the metal/support interface and the oxygen vacancies with the reducible supports like TiO2, ZrO2 and CeO2. Especially, for the reducible oxide supports, the EMSI effect normally enhances the activity of the Ru catalysts for CO2 methanation. However, the classic SMSI effect might cause the formation of the oxide overlayer on the Ru catalyst and shift the reaction from CO2 methanation to RWGS. This kind of SMSI effect must be avoided for CO2 methanation. CO2 methanation over the supported Ru catalyst is a structure sensitive reaction. Both structures of the support and the metal have the effect. By far, a structural controllable preparation of the supported Ru catalyst remains as a significant challenge. An effective way for the structure control is via the size control. Indeed, the size of the Ru catalyst has a significant effect on the activity and selectivity. The supported single Ru atom catalyst or the atomically dispersed Ru catalyst normally leads to the formation of CO via the RWGS reaction. For the selective hydrogenation of CO2 into methane, the Ru cluster or nanoparticle is required. Because of its strong CO binding, CO2 methanation over the supported Ru catalysts normally takes the CO related route. In conclusion, significant progresses have been recently made in the preparation and characterization of the supported Ru catalysts for CO2 methanation. Much more progresses can be expected in the near future. To further improve the supported Ru catalyst, the following aspects have to be considered. (1) As depicted in Fig. 1, the same reaction intermediate may lead to methane or CO or even methanol. In addition to the structures of the catalyst and the support, the effect of the micro-environment around the active site must be taken into consideration. (2) The catalyst preparation with a precise structural control is required. The future study on the effect of phase structure should be conducted at the same catalyst size, while the study of the size effect should be carried out with the same phase structure of the support. This might be a long-term investigation objective because of the challenges in the controllable preparation of the Ru catalysts on the porous supporting materials. Novel catalyst preparation technologies need to be developed. (3) The booming of advanced characterization techniques is very helpful for the understanding the electronic and geometric properties of the catalyst. For example, operando scanning tunneling microscope (STM) can be used for the atomic-scale observations of active sites such as the ruthenium/support interface, while environmental transmission electron microscope and in-situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy are conducive to decipher the dynamic evolution of the catalyst structure during the methanation process. It would be better to combine these characterizations with the theoretical studies. (4) Compared to the nickel catalyst, fewer papers can be found in the literature for the theoretical understanding of the structure-performance relation of the un-supported and supported Ru catalysts. Further theoretical studies on the effects of the structures of the support and the metal are immediately needed. Since there exist multi-active sites of the supported Ru catalyst, the multi-scale effects should be investigated with the consideration of the whole reaction network. (5) With the rapid development of data analysis and algorithm, high throughput simulation and machine learning have exhibited great potentials in theoretical catalysis. Once an appropriate descriptor for CO2 methanation is established, it would be highly expected to forecast the activity of any unknown catalyst. This is of great significance to screen novel and efficient ruthenium-based methanation catalysts. (6) The low temperature activity of the supported Ru catalysts for CO2 methanation needs to be further improved. There have been some studies with the use of the photothermal catalytic conversion [103,104]. More studies should be performed in the future with the intensified reaction technologies. Chang-jun Liu is a professor in the School of Chemical Engineering and Technology at Tianjin University, a Chang Jiang Distinguished Professor and Fellow of the Royal Society of Chemistry. His research interests include CO2 utilization, natural gas conversion, plasma nanoscience, and 3D printing. He has been in the list of highly cited Chinese authors (Chemical Engineering) by Elsevier since 2014. He served as the 2010 Program Chair of Fuel Chemistry Division of American Chemical Society and Chair of the 10th International Conference on CO2 Utilization. He is in the editorial board of Applied Catalysis B and Chinese Journal of Catalysis. He is in the advisory board of Journal of Energy Chemistry, Greenhouse Gases: Science & Technology, Journal of CO2 Utilization. Haibo Zhao is a professor in the School of Energy and Power Engineering at Huazhong University of Science and Technology. Prof. Haibo Zhao is also a Fellow of the Combustion Institute. His research interests include the low-carbon combustion and high-value utilization of fossil fuels, as well as the flame synthesis of functional nanoparticles. He has been supported by the National Science Fund for Distinguished Young Scholars of China, Alexander von Humboldt Foundation, etc. His research work won the Distinguished Paper Award in the 38th International Symposium on Combustion, and the Best Paper Award in the 3rd International Conference on Chemical Looping, etc. He served as an editorial board member or associate editor of Energy & Fuels, Engineering, and Energy Environmental Focus.

coredata.dc:description: CO2 methanation has a potential in the large-scale utilization of carbon dioxide. It has also been considered to be useful for the renewable energy storage. The commercial pipeline for natural gas transportation can be directly applied for the methane product of CO2 methanation. The supported ruthenium (Ru) catalyst has been confirmed to be active and stable for CO2 methanation with its high ability in the dissociation of hydrogen and the strong binding of carbon monoxide. CO2 methanation over the supported Ru catalyst is structure sensitive. The size of the Ru catalyst and the support have significant effects on the activity and the mechanism. A significant challenge remained is the structural controllable preparation of the supported Ru catalyst toward a sufficiently high low-temperature activity. In this review, the recent progresses in the investigations of the supported Ru catalysts for CO2 methanation are summarized. The challenges and the future developments are also discussed.
